;乌克兰总统 Volodymyr Zelensky 否认他的政府参与了对 Nord Stream 1 的破坏以及 2 条天然气管道，这是对德国出版集团 Axel Springer 标题的评论。

;

;“我是总裁，我会相应地发布命令。乌克兰没有做过任何此类事情。我永远不会那样做，”泽伦斯基说，并要求提供乌克兰参与的证据。

;

;乌克兰领导人周三发表的言论是对周二发表在《华盛顿邮报》上的一篇文章的回应。

;

; p>;

;《华盛顿邮报》曾报道称，美国政府从欧洲情报机构处获悉乌克兰军方利用潜水员攻击管道的秘密计划，后者直接向武装部队总司令报告了三个月在 2022 年 9 月爆炸之前。

;

;Nord Stream 1 和 Nord Stream 2 都在爆炸中严重受损，爆炸在丹麦博恩霍尔姆岛附近的管道上总共炸出了四个洞。海底管道将天然气从俄罗斯输送到德国。

;

;俄罗斯周四抓住这些报道，坚持要对爆炸进行调查。

;

;必须有一个“透明、国际和克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫 (Dmitry Peskov) 说：“对现在发生的事情进行紧急调查。”据《华盛顿邮报》报道，尽管美国政府最初无法独立证实这些报道，但仍与德国和其他国家的情报部门分享了这些信息。

;

;德国下议院联邦议院的成员随后也被告知。

;

;德国公共广播公司 NDR、WDR 和南德意志报大报的研究最近也得出结论，此案中有几条线索前往乌克兰方向。

;

;他们的报告说，有可疑的信箱公司和一个可能与乌克兰军方有联系的人。

;

;联邦检察官办公室和德国联邦政府已对这些报道发表评论。

;

;据俄罗斯国家通讯社塔斯社报道，佩斯科夫说：“我们不知道这些出版物在多大程度上符合现实。”但他表示，很明显，这是一起需要详细揭开的“混乱事件”。

;

;爆炸被广泛认为是破坏行为，尽管尚不清楚是谁进行了爆炸

;

;德国、瑞典和丹麦都在进行调查。

;

;美国国家安全委员会通讯主任约翰柯比周二拒绝就《华盛顿邮报》的报道发表评论。

;

;“我当然不会在讲台上讨论情报问题，”柯比在新闻发布会上告诉记者。 “在这种情况下，当然不会与《华盛顿邮报》所说的未经美国情报机构证实的人交谈。”

;

;尽管两国“两国国防部长于 11 月在柬埔寨会面，此后没有联系，尽管热线仍然存在。在华盛顿于 2 月击落一个据称是中国的间谍气球后，北京拒绝了奥斯汀与时任国防部长魏凤和通电话的要求。

;

;

;香港员工比新加坡员工更不愿意返回办公室一项国际调查发现，在 Covid-19 大流行期间，在家工作后在家工作的主要西方国家变得普遍。

;

;全球办公室设计咨询公司 Unispace 的调查发现，60% 的城市员工不愿意回到日常工作。

;

;这个数字高于英国 58%、新加坡 54%、美国 43% 和全球平均水平 51%。

;

;约 69% 的香港受访者表示，由于分心和会议次数过多，他们很难在办公室完成工作，与印度并列全球得分最高。

;

;共有 29% 的人表示他们在家里有更多的隐私，超过四分之一 (26%) 的人认为他们觉得离开办公室工作效率更高。

;

;“这些不喜欢主要是被雇主误解，他们认为员工返回工作场所的主要障碍是人们不想出差，21%，或者不喜欢在办公室和家之间携带工作设备（例如笔记本电脑），20%，” Unispace 报告称。

;

;Unispace 负责亚洲客户开发的高级负责人 Sean Moran 表示，问题的出现是因为管理者专注于业务，而员工专注于个人福祉——这引起了双方的不满。< /p>;

;“我们的研究表明，雇主与雇员之间的严重脱节导致了香港艰难的工作环境和文化，”他说。

;

;“香港企业需要了解他们的员工的担忧和挣扎，从工作安排和办公室生产力到倦怠。”

;

;为什么香港人与“老派”老板就重返办公室展开拉锯战

;

;莫兰补充道：“重要的是，您要为这些人提供正确的解决方案，以及推动事情发展的灵活性和信任，[然后]您自然会看到绩效和生产力的提高。”

;

;民意调查还显示，在调查中，64% 的城市雇员经常有感到精疲力竭的时期。

;

;几乎一半（45%）的人将这种感觉主要归因于工作量，38% 的人表示这是因为雇主期望员工必须始终在家在线。

;

;但企业坚称，员工无法有效地平衡时间是造成问题的主要原因。

;

;由于混合工作成为主流，改造您的工作场所需要多少成本？

;

;这项香港调查涉及来自大中型公司的 500 多名员工和 100 多名高级管理人员，是一项调查的一部分Unispace 于 4 月 3 日至 14 日进行的全球民意调查。

;

;国际民意调查包括来自 17 个国家和地区的 9,500 多名员工和 6,650 名商界领袖。

;

;许多香港公司允许它的员工在 Covid-19 大流行期间在家工作，但随着城市努力恢复正常，许多人要求他们的员工返回办公室。

;

;有些人辞去了工作，而不是去上班，而是为了更灵活的安排回到日常通勤。

;

;专业服务公司普华永道去年 3 月对全市 1,043 名员工进行了调查，发现十分之九的员工更愿意远程工作，但只有 45% 的人可以选择。

;中国、巴基斯坦和伊朗已同意在首次会谈后定期举行反恐会谈关于地区安全问题的三边会议。

;

;中国外交部对外安全事务司司长白天在北京会见了巴基斯坦和伊朗外长，回顾了地区反恐努力并讨论了“应对十字路口”的联合行动- 恐怖分子的边境流动”，根据该部的一份声明。

;

;白还分别与巴基斯坦外交部总干事阿卜杜勒·哈米德和赛义德·拉苏尔·莫萨维进行了一对一的会谈，外交部部长助理兼伊朗外交部南亚司司长。

;

;中国外交部部长助理农荣还分别主持了与哈米德和莫萨维的会谈。

;

;“[三位中国外交部发言人汪文斌表示，双方决定将三方反恐安全磋商机制化，并将该磋商机制描述为中国 2 月份提出的“全球安全倡议”的一部分。

;

;“中方坚决反对并强烈反对谴责一切形式的恐怖主义，并愿意与巴基斯坦和伊朗密切合作，打击威胁三个国家利益和地区安全的恐怖势力，”王在周四的例行新闻发布会上说。

;< p>;北京中国现代国际关系研究院研究员李伟表示，三方对话具有“非常重要的意义”，将主要关注防止阿富汗武装的溢出效应。

;

;“一带一路基础设施建设面临的恐怖主义威胁也将成为讨论的话题，”李说。

;

;中国敦促巴基斯坦、阿富汗在 2021 年以来的首次会谈中帮助打击恐怖主义;

;自两年前塔利班武装分子在喀布尔推翻美国支持的政府以来，巴基斯坦频繁发生恐怖袭击，随之而来的动荡为反华叛乱组织巴基斯坦塔利班运动提供了发展空间，同时被称为巴基斯坦塔利班。激进组织伊斯兰国是塔利班的主要竞争对手，自塔利班接管以来在该地区也变得更加活跃。

;

;“塔利班上台……导致极端主义在中南亚重新活跃，包括伊朗，因为中国西北大学教授闫伟说：“当旧政权被新政权取代时，新秩序正在建立。”

;

;随着极端势力的影响正在跨越国界，他说，需要多边机制来化解风险。

;

;该地区的一些恐怖袭击针对的是中国公民，尤其是那些在“一带一路”倡议项目上工作的人。去年 12 月，ISIS 在阿富汗的分支机构 Islamic State Khorasan (Isis-K) 声称对喀布尔一家深受中国商人欢迎的酒店发动的致命恐怖袭击负责。

;

;塔利班称在喀布尔中国人背后袭击了 Isis 网络成员酒店袭击

;

;“这些附近国家的安全肯定会对我们产生影响，特别是因为我们是巴基斯坦的邻居，而伊朗是我们的远邻，”闫说。

;

;中国近年来与伊朗和巴基斯坦建立了更加密切的关系，包括与伊朗签署了为期25年的合作协议，并在“一带一路”战略下建立了中巴经济走廊。

;

;“这[安全对话机制] 可能是验证每一方是否有兴趣进行更雄心勃勃的三边对话的第一步，”新加坡国立大学中东研究所高级研究员 Jean-Loup Samaan 说。

;< p>;中国也在巩固其今年早些时候在促进沙特阿拉伯和伊朗之间紧张局势缓和方面所发挥的作用所带来的势头，新机制可能会为“中国重塑地区外交环境的雄心”增添新的维度，萨曼说。

;

;近几个月来，中国加大了在包括中东和乌克兰在内的一些全球热点地区促成和平的努力。

;

;3 月，它带来了沙特阿拉伯和伊朗在北京共同寻求在七年的敌对之后恢复双边关系。中国还与乌克兰和俄罗斯接触，讨论一项潜在的和平计划，尽管承认这两个交战方之间很难达成协议。

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 21:50:02 +0800 China’s state banks cut deposit rates to bolster economy, but officials at Lujiazui Forum remain tight-lippedhttps://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3223402/chinas-state-banks-cut-deposit-rates-bolster-economy-officials-lujiazui-forum-remain-tight-lipped?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.08 21:00;
;;

;China's big five state-owned banks lowered deposit rates for the first time this year on Thursday with the market bracing for further weak indicators and calls for more policies to address the economic woes, but top financial officials offered little clues on the opening day of a key forum.

;

;Instead, officials said China's economy was resilient and improving – words often used by Beijing to downplay a strong stimulus – at the opening session of the two-day Lujiazui Forum in Shanghai.

;

;Market players, though, are discussing a potential policy rate cut by the central bank as a strong signal to shore up the economy.

;

;In a concerted action, the five leading banks - including the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the Bank of China and the Bank of Communications - reduced their current account deposit rate by 5 basis points to 0.2 per cent on Thursday.

;

;4 takeaways from China's May trade data as exports tumbled

;

;They also reduced their three-year and five-year deposit rates by 15 basis points to 2.45 per cent and 2.5 per cent, respectively.

;

;“This new round of deposit rate cuts, as well as rapidly worsening exports, broadening property distress, ongoing disinflation, and a likely [US Federal reserve] pause [in interest rate increases], raise our conviction of this call on rate cuts,” Japanese investment bank Nomura said.

;

;Many institutions have warned that the world's second-largest economy is now at a crossroads as post-reopening domestic demand is failing to offset falling overseas orders, a looming local debt crisis, while it is also facing deflationary risks and staggering investor confidence.

;

;Economists from leading investment bank Citic Securities also raised the issue of a possible policy rate cut, which would be the first since August, saying that China has already entered an important window for economic stabilisation.

;

;The Lujiazui Forum is a major platform to sense Beijing's midyear evaluation of the current economic and financial conditions, their policy intentions and any U-turns planned at the quarterly meeting of Politburo in late July.

;

;Li Yunze, head of the new National Financial Regulatory Administration, said at the forum on Thursday that China's economic development has continued to recover and improve, while market demand has recovered steadily and positive factors have continued to increase.

;

;“It is key to recover and expand effective demand, and we'll continue to improve financial services,” said Li, who was appointed as the party chief of the new financial regulator in May.

;

;He briefly mentioned more financing support for new energy vehicles, green home appliances, reconstruction of urban villages in big cities, public infrastructures, tech development, advanced manufacturing and private firms before focusing on the prevention of financial risk.

;

;China's new regulator vows to 'build an iron wall of financial security'

;

;People's Bank of China governor Yi Gang, meanwhile, devoted his whole speech at the forum on Thursday to green finance and China's carbon neutral goals.

;

;Yi, who has refrained from using a big stimulus during his tenure since 2018, showed reluctance to slash policy rates – including the one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) – earlier this year.

;

;“Our major parameters of monetary policy stay at a reasonable level, and the real interest rate level is also appropriate,” he said in March.

;

;China's central bank, instead, cut the reserve requirement ratio for commercial banks by 25 basis points in late March, injecting 500 billion yuan (US$70.2 billion) of funds into the market after lowering the amount of cash that banks must hold in reserve.

;

;Economic conditions and investor sentiment in China weakened quickly in April and May, however, raising concerns the post-coronavirus recovery was losing momentum.

;

;In another slew of disappointing figures released this week, exports tumbled by 7.5 per cent from a year earlier in May, reversing from April's growth.

;

;The official manufacturing purchasing manager's index also dropped to a five-month low of 48.8 last month.

;

;China is widely believed to have many resources and tools to deal with its economic problems, including insufficient demand and local debt crisis, and it is seen as being able to reach its around 5 per cent gross domestic product growth target for this year because of the low comparison base in 2022.

;

;China's consumer, factory-gate inflation woes enhance 'great need' for support

;

;And unlike its Western peers whose hands are tied by the high inflation, China's monetary authority faces less restraint because April's consumer price index grew by only 0.1 per cent.

;

;The central government also has lots of financial resources, with a much lower leverage ratio than developed countries.

;

;Around 200 billion yuan (US$28 billion) of one-year MLF will mature on June 15, and it is an important occasion to see if policymakers will adjust its rates.

;

;June's loan prime rates will then be released on June 20, with the central bank having kept its benchmark lending rates unchanged for the ninth month in May.

;

;Additional reporting by Mandy Zuo

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 21:20:02 +0800 What next for controversial plan to build public housing on exclusive Hong Kong golf course?https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3223435/what-next-controversial-plan-build-public-housing-exclusive-hong-kong-golf-course?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.08 20:39;
;;

;A controversial plan to build thousands of public housing flats on part of an exclusive golf course is back under the spotlight after the Hong Kong government on Monday said it would revise the scheme and temporarily change the site's proposed use from “residential” to “undetermined”.

;

;The government's move has sparked questions on whether it will proceed with the plan, among efforts to fix the city's long-standing housing shortage, while the Hong Kong Golf Club and heavyweights from different sectors are increasing their efforts to save the earmarked section of the 172-hectare Fanling course from redevelopment.

;

;The Post examines the twists and turns of the proposal.

;

;1. What's the plan?

;

;The scheme was among short- to medium-term proposals suggested five years ago by the now-defunct Task Force on Land Supply, which launched a months-long public debate on tackling the shortage of housing sites during then chief executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor's term in office.

;

;Tournament will not disrupt housing plans for Hong Kong golf course: officials

;

;Before Lam's term ended last June, the government laid out its plans for the 32-hectare Old Course at Fanling, with the golf club to return the land. The plan involves a 9.5-hectare site earmarked for building 12,000 public housing flats for about 33,600 people by 2029, with the remaining area reserved for recreational and conservation uses.

;

;The exclusive Hong Kong Golf Club, which will return the Old Course to the government in September, strongly opposes the plan. It says the ecology of the city's oldest golf course will be damaged.

;

;Politicians, businessmen and housing advisers are among those backing the club. Regina Ip Lau Suk-yee, convenor of Hong Kong's top decision-making Executive Council and a club member, previously urged the government to abandon the plan.

;

;2. What are the latest developments?

;

;The government on Monday said it would temporarily change the proposed use of the 9.5-hectare site from “residential” to “undetermined” to buy time for amending the housing layout and density as requested by environmental authorities.

;

;The Environmental Protection Department last month approved the plan on condition its visual impact was minimised and 0.4 hectares of woodland preserved in accordance with suggestions from the Advisory Council on the Environment.

;

;The advisers made their recommendations last month after failing to reach a consensus in a previous meeting in August, when a decision was due.

;

;The golf club, meanwhile, is continuing with efforts to save the Old Course, revealing that it is in the running to host a Saudi Arabia-backed LIV Golf League event next year, which it says it can act as a bridge between China and the Middle East.

;

;When it returns the land to the government, the golf club will still have two complete 18-hole courses plus 10 holes for a third course. But it said on Monday the Old Course had been used for parking and storing equipment for past events, and warned Hong Kong could lose out on high-profile tournaments in the future if the plan went ahead.

;

;Exco convenor Ip on Wednesday urged the government to review how to use the land and its decision to take back the site.

;

;3. Will homes be built on the golf course?

;

;Development chief Bernadette Linn Hon-ho on Wednesday said the intention to build public housing in the area remained “unchanged” but the number of flats was likely to be cut.

;

;“Whether we can maintain the construction amount of 12,000 after the review, I think the objective conditions are telling us that we may not be able to do this,” she said.

;

;“If I emptily promise today that we could hit the target regardless, then it would be equal to me saying that I do not need to pay attention to the demands placed on us by the environmental impact assessment procedures.”

;

;The government said it would strive to house residents by 2031, two years later than the proposed target.

;

;Linn also said a proposal raised by rural body the Heung Yee Kuk for a project of a similar scale was no “substitute” for the golf course plan, noting the suggested site had scattered private ownership and there was no road access.

;

;Hong Kong rural body proposes housing scheme near controversial golf club site

;

;Rural leaders on Tuesday suggested building 12,000 public flats in Ping Kong Tsuen, a village with abandoned farmland and some squatter huts located next to the golf course. Landowners will receive compensation if the government reclaims their land.

;

;4. What are the concerns?

;

;Brian Wong Shiu-hung, a member of the Liber Research Community, an NGO focusing on land issues, said the government's latest move left the public with a negative impression.

;

;“Consensus was reached on the golf course housing project during the land debate five years ago … It makes people question whether the government will still implement the plan,” Wong said.

;

;The Society for Community Organisation, an NGO serving the underprivileged, said the government was too slow in implementing the project when the average waiting time for a public rental flat was 5.3 years as of March.

;

;“It has a huge impact on those waiting for public housing,” Sze said. “Every project receives opposition. Does it mean we give up on all of them?”

;

;Developing Hong Kong farmland 'no substitute' for building housing on golf course

;

;5. What happens next?

;

;The Town Planning Board, a statutory body that assesses land applications, will hold five public hearings this month on the overall redevelopment plan starting on Monday.

;

;Golf club representatives, business heavyweights and housing concern groups are expected to show up and express their views, while the board earlier received more than 6,500 responses against the housing proposal.

;

;Despite the change in the proposed land use, the board still has to make a decision on the overall redevelopment plan of the golf course by the end of November at the latest.

;

;Afterwards, the government will start amending the proposal and submit a new plan to environmental authorities by the end of next year.

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 20:50:02 +0800 Beijing calls on US to let Hong Kong leader John Lee attend San Francisco Apec meeting in Novemberhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3223426/beijing-calls-us-let-hong-kong-leader-john-lee-attend-san-francisco-apec-meeting-november?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;Beijing has called on Washington to fulfil its obligations as the host of an Asia-Pacific summit later this year and allow Hong Kong leader John Lee Ka-chiu to attend.

;

;China's foreign ministry spoke out on Thursday after a bipartisan group of United States congressmen appealed to the Biden administration to bar Lee from entering the country to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) forum event in San Francisco in November.

;

;The congressmen earlier said Lee was “a sanctioned human rights abuser” and his attendance at the meeting would be “an affront to all those who have been persecuted by the Chinese Communist Party and the People's Republic of China and its proxies in Hong Kong”.

;

;But ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin said Apec had its own house rules and the host country had the responsibility to ensure all members were able to attend meetings.

;

;He added the US had pledged to fulfil its obligations as host, follow Apec rules and help members attend meetings.

;

;“We believe the US would fulfil the obligations and would ensure all Apec members, including Hong Kong, China, can attend the meeting without incident,” he said.

;

;Hong Kong joined Apec in 1991 and continued to take part in meetings after the city was returned to Chinese rule in 1997 as a separate and full member under the name “Hong Kong, China”.

;

;The city is represented by the chief executive at the organisation's economic leaders' meeting and by the commerce and economic development secretary at ministerial meetings.

;

;But Lee is one of the Chinese officials sanctioned by Washington in 2020 after Beijing imposed the national security law on Hong Kong.

;

;The US claimed the legislation undermined the city's autonomy and restricted the freedoms and rights of its people.

;

;US must 'act in accordance with conventions', invite Hong Kong to Apec: Lee

;

;Lee put the ball in the organisers' court last month when he was asked about whether he would attend the San Francisco summit.

;

;He said Washington had a responsibility to “act in accordance with convention” and invite Apec members. Government sources have also said they hoped the restriction could be lifted by November.

;

;A US State Department spokesman said in May invitations for the event had not been finalised.

;

;Lau Siu-kai, a consultant at Beijing's semi-official think tank, the Chinese Association of Hong Kong and Macau Studies, said Washington could consider issuing a single entry visa to Lee so he could attend the meeting.

;

;But he said US internal politics could complicate how the Apec summit was handled because the Democratic Party's Joe Biden faced a presidential election in 2024.

;

;“Joe Biden, who is seeking a second term, may be criticised for being too weak to China or Hong Kong if he makes too many concessions,” Lau explained.

;

;Trips to US and UK to be made by top Hong Kong officials, first in 3 years

;

;He added that the call for a ban was this time made by a bipartisan group, not just members of the opposition Republican Party.

;

;“But whether Hong Kong or Beijing would accept the arrangement of a one-off visa is another story,” Lau, who was recently appointed as a Hong Kong government expert adviser on policy, said.

;

;He highlighted the recent attempt by Washington to arrange a meeting between the US and Chinese defence ministers in Singapore – which was rejected by Beijing.

;

;“Beijing simply said 'no'. To the Zhongnanhai leadership, it is a matter of principle. You cannot just sanction me as you like but then ask me to talk with you by offering to lift the sanction temporarily,” he said.

;

;Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development Algernon Yau Ying-wah last month attended an Apec ministers meeting in Detroit and spoke about the need to foster sustainable and inclusive trade in the region.
